coredata.dc:title: An in-situ strategy to analyze multi-effect catalysis in iron-copper bimetals catalyzed Fenton-like processes
coredata.dc:creator: Ren, Yi
Yu, Jinyan
Zhang, Jingyue
Lv, Lu
Zhang, Weiming
coredata.dc:description: Iron-copper bimetals for Fenton-like catalysis were developed, due to efficient enhancement of catalytic activity by iron-copper synergy. However, deviation exists in mechanism analysis of multi-effect catalysis. In this study, a new in-situ strategy of shielding Fe(II) and Cu(I) from further reaction by trapping agents was developed, for analysis of iron catalysis alone, copper catalysis alone and synergistic effect in bimetallic catalyst systems. Inhibition efficiency and influence of trapping agents on Fe(II)/Cu(I) catalysis were quantitatively evaluated for reliability confirmation and method correction. The possible application scope was identified as pH of 4–6, and this strategy was available for analysis of five different groups of catalysts. The potential superiority and difference of the proposed strategy compared with current ex-situ strategy were also analyzed. The overestimation (12.1%–35.4%) of copper catalysis and biased analysis (0.1%–12.6%) of iron catalysis by ex-situ strategy can be alleviated, thereby improving accuracy for synergistic effect. In summary, this study proposed a new strategy to improve the understanding of iron-copper bimetallic catalysis, which can provide reference for other polymetallic catalysis analysis development.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Inhibition efficiency of different trapping agents on HO• generation in (a) Fe2O3 & CuO, (b) Fe/Al2O3 & Cu/Al2O3, and (c) MIL(Fe) & MIL(Cu) catalyzed Fenton-like systems. Experimental conditions: T = 30 °C, [BA]0 = 10 mmol/L, [H2O2]0 = 10 mmol/L, pH = 5.0, [neocuproine]0 = 0.5 mmol/L, [BPY]0 = 2 mmol/L, and [ferrozine]0 = 2 mmol/L.

Influence of different trapping agents on HO• generation in (a) CuO & Fe2O3, (b) Fe/Al2O3 & Cu/Al2O3, and (c) MIL(Fe) & MIL(Cu) catalyzed Fenton-like systems. Experimental conditions: T = 30 °C, [BA]0 = 10 mmol/L, [H2O2]0 = 10 mmol/L, pH = 5.0, [neocuproine]0 = 0.5 mmol/L, [BPY]0 = 2 mmol/L, and [ferrozine]0 = 2 mmol/L.

(a) Inhibition efficiency, and (b) influence rate* of different trapping agents in different Fenton-like systems. * Influence rate indicates the decrease rate of HO• generation caused by the influence of trapping agents on non-target metals.

Effect of pH on inhibition efficiency for HO• generation of different trapping agents in (a) Fe/Al2O3, (b) Cu/Al2O3, and (c) Fe/Cu/Al2O3 catalyzed Fenton-like systems. Experimental conditions: T = 30 °C, [BA]0 = 10 mmol/L, [H2O2]0 = 10 mmol/L, [neocuproine]0 = 0.5 mmol/L, and [ferrozine]0 = 2 mmol/L.

HO• generation in (a) CuFe2O4, (b) Fe/Cu/Al2O3, (c) Cu/Fe-SBA-15, (d) Cu/Fe/SBA-15, and (e) MIL(Fe/Cu) catalyzed Fenton-like systems with different trapping agent addition. Experimental conditions: T = 30 °C, [BA]0 = 10 mmol/L, [H2O2]0 = 10 mmol/L, pH = 5.0, [neocuproine]0 = 0.5 mmol/L, [BPY]0 = 2 mmol/L, and [ferrozine]0 = 2 mmol/L.
Effect for HO• generation of iron alone catalysis, copper alone catalysis and synergistic effect in Fenton-like systems with different iron-copper-based catalysts analyzed by in-situ strategy.

Effect for HO• generation of iron alone catalysis, copper alone catalysis and synergistic effect in Fenton-like systems with different iron-copper-based catalysts analyzed by in-situ strategy (after correction) and ex-situ strategy.

head.ce:title: An in-situ strategy to analyze multi-effect catalysis in iron-copper bimetals catalyzed Fenton-like processes

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Iron-copper bimetals for Fenton-like catalysis were developed, due to efficient enhancement of catalytic activity by iron-copper synergy. However, deviation exists in mechanism analysis of multi-effect catalysis. In this study, a new in-situ strategy of shielding Fe(II) and Cu(I) from further reaction by trapping agents was developed, for analysis of iron catalysis alone, copper catalysis alone and synergistic effect in bimetallic catalyst systems. Inhibition efficiency and influence of trapping agents on Fe(II)/Cu(I) catalysis were quantitatively evaluated for reliability confirmation and method correction. The possible application scope was identified as pH of 4–6, and this strategy was available for analysis of five different groups of catalysts. The potential superiority and difference of the proposed strategy compared with current ex-situ strategy were also analyzed. The overestimation (12.1%–35.4%) of copper catalysis and biased analysis (0.1%–12.6%) of iron catalysis by ex-situ strategy can be alleviated, thereby improving accuracy for synergistic effect. In summary, this study proposed a new strategy to improve the understanding of iron-copper bimetallic catalysis, which can provide reference for other polymetallic catalysis analysis development.

ce:section.ce:para:
Iron-based heterogeneous Fenton-like processes have been widely used for water and wastewater treatment [1–3], due to the advantages of high oxidation efficiency, wide pH range for application, low negative effects, etc [4–6]. However, the catalytic activity still needs to be further strengthened for better oxidation efficiency. In iron-based Fenton-like processes, HO• production needs the reaction of Fe(II) and oxidants (Eq. (1)), and regeneration of Fe(II) (Eq. (2)) is rate-limiting step generally [7,8]. In recent years, several methods, such as light/electrochemical assistance, catalyst modification, reductants addition, etc. were developed to enhance the reaction rate of the rate-limiting step in Fenton-like processes [9–13]. Another metal incorporation in heterogeneous catalysts, such as copper, cobalt or nickel, is a strategy to overcome the limitation as well, with the advantages of low negative effects and high efficiency [14–17]. Among these metals, due to low cost, low toxicity, and high efficiency, copper is the most common one used for iron-based bimetallic catalyst synthesis. The additional copper can catalyze H2O2 decomposition for HO• generation as well (Eqs. (3) and (4)) [16,18]. More importantly, the reduction of Fe(III) by Cu(I) (Eq. (5)) (i.e., synergistic effect) can facilitate the regeneration of Fe(II) in iron-copper catalysis [16,19].
(1) Fe(II) + H2O2 → Fe(III) + HO• + OH-
(2) Fe(III) + H2O2 → Fe(II) + HO2 • + H+
(3) Cu(I) + H2O2 → Cu(II) + HO• + OH-
(4) Cu(II) + H2O2 → Cu(I) + HO2 • + H+
(5) Fe(III) + Cu(I) → Fe(II) + Cu(II)

Development of iron-copper bimetallic catalysts is a research hotspot in recent years. However, the catalysis mechanisms of iron-copper synergy are still confusing, and further efforts need to be put into understanding multi-effect catalysis. Currently, contribution of iron or copper alone catalysis is usually determined by the corresponding monometallic catalysts, and synergistic effect is concluded according to the difference of catalytic efficiency between bimetallic catalysts and monometallic catalysts [20,21]. However, the dispersion, morphology and actual mass loading of iron/copper in monometallic catalysts might be greatly different from those in bimetallic catalysts. This can influence the contribution identification of iron alone and copper alone catalysis, thereby influencing the analysis of iron-copper synergy. Moreover, Cu(I) amount for copper catalyzed Fenton-like process (Eq. (3)) might be different in bimetallic catalyst and monometallic catalyst systems, due to the absence of Eq. (5) for Cu(I) consumption in monometallic catalyst systems, which leads to misunderstanding of multi-effect catalysis.

Some complexing agents of Fe(II) and Cu(I), such as 2,2′-bipyridine (BPY, complexing agent of Fe(II)), ferrozine (complexing agent of Fe(II)) and neocuproine (complexing agent of Cu(I)) were used as trapping agents in previous studies, preventing reaction between Fe(II)/Cu(I) and H2O2 (i.e., Eqs. (1) and (3)), thereby suppressing iron- or copper-based Fenton-like process [7,8,22,23]. For instance, Tong et al. [23] used BPY as a trapping agent to investigate the contribution of adsorbed Fe(II) in subsurface sediments for radicals generation. Yang et al. [7] developed ferrozine as a reagent to selectively complex with Fe(II) for better determination of Fe(II) generation in CNTs-mediated Fe(III)/H2O2 systems. Dong et al. [24] developed neocuproine as Cu(I) scavenger to investigate the efficiency of Cu(I) in zero-valent copper for methyl orange removal. Consequently, we considered using the existing trapping agents and exploiting a new method for analysis of multi-effect catalysis in iron-copper bimetallic Fenton-like systems. With copper trapping agent, copper alone and synergistic catalysis can be inhibited; with iron trapping agent, iron alone and synergistic catalysis can be inhibited. This method can achieve in-situ analysis, and might avoid the influence of difference between iron/copper in monometallic catalysts and those in bimetallic catalysts.

Nevertheless, such strategy for iron-copper bimetallic catalysis still faces problems. The trapping agents suppress Fenton-like processes by generating complexed Fe(II)/Cu(I) and slowing down the reaction of Fe(II)/Cu(I). However, if trapping agents cannot complex all formed Fe(II)/Cu(I), or the complexed Fe(II)/Cu(I) still can react with H2O2 or the other metal, the inhibition efficiency might be influenced. In addition, as organic complexing agents, trapping agents might influence non-target metals (e.g., BPY and ferrozine on Cu(I), neocuproine on Fe(II)). Furthermore, trapping agents might compete for active species (e.g., HO•) with model pollutants, and thus decline the removal efficiencies. All above problems might significantly influence the analysis of multi-effect catalysis, and make the in-situ strategy development insignificant.

Therefore, in this study, we tried to develop a new in-situ strategy for analysis of multi-effect catalysis in bimetals catalyzed Fenton-like systems, as well as comprehensively evaluate and analyze the proposed strategy, using five different kinds of iron-copper bimetallic catalysts, two Fe(II) trapping agents, and one Cu(I) trapping agent. Dispersion, morphology, species, structure, etc. of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts were characterized for auxiliary analysis of the reliability of the proposed strategy. To overcome the competition of active species by trapping agents during analytic processes, after active species determination, an excessive dose of benzoic acid (BA, 10 mmol/L) was used to trap and test the concentration of HO•. Multi-effect catalysis was investigated based on the concentration of HO• generation. Inhibition efficiency and influence of different trapping agents on Fe(II) and Cu(I) catalysis were evaluated by monometallic catalyst systems. Effect of pH on inhibition efficiency was also investigated for applied scope determination. In addition, we tried to analyze bimetallic catalyst systems by this strategy, and calculate and correct the results based on the inhibition efficiency and influence rate. The results were also compared with those obtained by the current ex-situ method. We expected to establish a new in-situ strategy for mechanisms analysis of multi-effect catalysis in iron-copper bimetallic catalyst systems with high reliability and accuracy.

SBA-15 molecular sieve and iron doped SBA-15 molecular sieve (Fe-SBA-15) were purchased from 3A Materials. Superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Acetonitrile and methanol of chromatographic grade were purchased from Merck KGaA. Phosphoric acid and acetic acid of chromatographic grade, and 2,9-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline (neocuproine) of analytical grade were purchased from Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. Other reagents, including benzoic acid, bisphenol S (BPS), BPY, ferrozine, NaOH, H2SO4, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30%), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, citric acid, Al2O3, terephthalic acid, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, FeCl3·6H2O, tert-butyl alcohol (TBA), chloroform (TF), etc. of analytical grade were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd.

CuFe2O4 was synthesized by the sol-gel combustion method [25]. Fe2O3 was synthesized by directly calcining Fe(NO3)3·9H2O at 400 °C. CuO was synthesized by directly calcining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O at 400 °C. Fe/Cu/Al2O3, Fe/Al2O3, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/Fe-SBA-15, Cu/SBA-15, Cu/Fe/SBA-15 and Fe/SBA-15 were synthesized by the impregnation-calcination method. MIL(Fe/Cu), MIL(Fe) and MIL(Cu) were synthesized by the hydrothermal method. Details pertaining to the synthesis of catalysts in this study are provided in the Supplementary Material (Text S1).

The experiments were conducted in beakers. 10 mmol/L BA solution was used for HO• determination, and pH was adjusted by adding H2SO4 or NaOH solution. The catalysts were divided into five groups: (i) Fe2O3, CuO and CuFe2O4; (ii) Fe/Al2O3, Cu/Al2O3 and Fe/Cu/Al2O3; (iii)Fe-SBA-15, Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/Fe-SBA-15; (iv)Fe/SBA-15, Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/Fe/SBA-15; (v) MIL(Fe/Cu), MIL(Fe) and MIL(Cu). To keep same theoretical iron and/or copper addition in each group, the particle dosage of CuFe2O4, Fe2O3, CuO, Fe/Cu/Al2O3, Fe/Al2O3, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/Fe-SBA-15, Fe-SBA-15, Cu/SBA-15, Cu/Fe/SBA-15, Fe/SBA-15, MIL(Fe/Cu), MIL(Fe) and MIL(Cu) is 1000 mg/L, 668 mg/L, 333 mg/L, 1000 mg/L, 1000 mg/L, 1000 mg/L, 1000 mg/L, 938 mg/L, 1000 mg/L, 1000 mg/L, 1000 mg/L, 1000 mg/L, 667 mg/L and 333 mg/L, respectively. The reaction was initiated by adding 10 mmol/L H2O2 after saturated adsorption of each catalyst. The trapping agents including neocuproine (0.5 mmol/L), BPY (2 mmol/L) and ferrozine (2 mmol/L) were dissolved into BA solution before used in trapping experiments. During the reaction, 2 mL samples were taken from the beaker at specified time intervals for HO• determination. The concentration of HO• generation was detected by the determination of hydroxylated product of BA, i.e., p-hydroxybenzoic acid (p-HBA), with a proportionality factor of 5.9 [26,27]. Inhibition efficiency indicates the decrease rate of HO• generation caused by the inhibition of trapping agents on target metals. Influence rate indicates the decrease rate of HO• generation caused by the influence of trapping agents on non-target metals.

To evaluate the reactive oxygen species generation, quenching experiments were conducted with 40 μmmol/L BPS solution. Effect of different scavengers for reactive oxygen species quenching was evaluated by BPS removal efficiency. The scavengers including TBA (30 mmol/L), TF (10 mmol/L), CAT (500 mg/L) and SOD (30 mg/L) were added into BPS solution before 10 mmol/L H2O2 adding. During the reaction, 2 mL samples were taken from the beaker at specified time intervals as well for residual BPA determination. All above obtained samples were filtered through hydrophilic polyethersulfone (PES) syringe filters (0.22 µm) to remove particles, and methanol was added immediately to quench the formed reactive oxygen species.

The concentrations of p-HBA and BPS in solution were measured by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, U3000, Dionex, US) with a C18 column (5 µm, 250 × 4.6 mm, Agilent, US) and a UV detector at 256 and 258 nm. The mobile phase consisted of 0.05% phosphoric acid solution/acetonitrile (v/v, 60/40), and 0.1% acetic acid solution/methanol (v/v, 40/60) for p-HBA and BPS determination, respectively, at a flow rate of 0.8 mL/min. For electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra detection, same particle dosage and H2O2 concentration with beaker experiments, 10 μmmol/L DMPO, and 100 mmol/L methanol (if necessary) were added into the solution (pH = 5). The samples were obtained by capillary tubes and then detected by an EPR A300 spectrometer (EMX 10/12, Bruker, Germany). The surface morphology of different catalysts was observed by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Quanta 250, FEI, US). The composition and structure of different catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction with an EMPYREAN diffractometer (XRD, CAD4/PC, Enraf Noius, Holland), a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, NEXUS870, Nicolet, US), and a Raman spectrometer (Dxr2xi, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Germany) with excitation wavelength of 532 nm. Diffuse reflectance in the region of 200–2500 nm was performed by a UV/VIS/NIR spectrometer (UV3600 plus, Shimadzu, Japan). The chemical states of iron and copper in different catalysts were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI 5000 VersaProbe, UIVAC-PHI, Japan). Zeta potential of different catalysts was analyzed by a Zetasizer (Nano ZS90, Malvern Instruments, UK).

Five groups of iron-copper-based catalysts: (i) Fe2O3, CuO and CuFe2O4; (ii) Fe/Al2O3, Cu/Al2O3 and Fe/Cu/Al2O3; (iii) Fe-SBA-15, Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/Fe-SBA-15; (iv) Fe/SBA-15, Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/Fe/SBA-15; (v) MIL(Fe/Cu), MIL(Fe) and MIL(Cu) were used as representatives of iron-copper bimetallic catalysts. These catalysts were characterized by SEM, XRD, FTIR and XPS to identify the properties of iron and copper. In the first group, as shown in Fig. S1, XRD spectra of CuFe2O4, Fe2O3 and CuO are similar to the standard spectra from Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS File No. 34–0425 (CuFe2O4, copper ferrite), 33–0664 (Fe2O3, hematite) and 80–1268 (CuO, tenorite)). These results indicate that these three compounds were synthesized successfully. XPS spectra in Fig. S2(a) and (f) show that Fe 2p binding energy positions of CuFe2O4 and Fe2O3 are near 723.8/710.7 eV and 724.2/710.8 eV, respectively, which are close to Fe(III) state; Cu 2p binding energy positions of CuFe2O4 and CuO are near 953.7/933.8 eV and 953.9/934.0 eV, respectively, which are close to Cu(II) state[28,29]. These results further identify the synthesis of these three catalysts with Fe(III) and Cu(II). However, peaks in XRD spectra and binding energy of iron and copper in XPS spectra are not the same in these catalysts, suggesting the difference of iron and copper species in CuFe2O4 and Fe2O3/CuO. SEM images in Fig. S3(a)-(c) indicate that these three particles and easy to aggregate without support, with particle size of nano and sub-micron scale. Due to the lack of functional groups, FTIR results of these iron/copper oxides catalysts (Fig. S4(a)-(c)) seem meaningless. FTIR spectra will be analyzed in group (v), the catalysts of which contain organic ligands.

Groups (ii) and (iv) represent the bimetallic catalysts with supported iron and copper, and group (iii) represents that with doped iron and supported copper. As shown in Fig. S1 (b), the characteristic peaks of Fe2O3 near 33.2° and 35.6° appear in XRD spectra of Fe/Al2O3 and Fe/Cu/Al2O3; as shown in Fig. S2 (c), the characteristic peaks of CuO near 35.5° and 38.7° appear in XRD spectra of Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/Fe-SBA-15. No reflections associating with CuO and Fe2O3 in some catalysts might be caused by the content and dimensions of them on support materials below the detection limitation [30,31]. Successful incorporation of iron and copper in the catalysts can be proved by XPS results. XPS spectra of group (ii) show that Fe 2p binding energy positions of Fe/Cu/Al2O3 and Fe/Al2O3 are near 724.7/711.3 eV and 724.6/711.2 eV, respectively, and Cu 2p binding energy positions of Fe/Cu/Al2O3 and Cu/Al2O3 are near 953.2/933.2 eV. The similar positions further represent the similar chemical states of Fe(III) and Cu(II). Due to the low density of SBA-15 (Fe-SBA-15), the amount of iron and copper in them is less, with same volume for XPS detection of SBA-15 (Fe-SBA-15)-based catalysts. Therefore, the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in XPS (Fe 2p and Cu 2p) spectra (Fig. S2 (c)-(d) and (h)-(i)) is low, which was also faced by previous studies in BSA-15-based systems [30,32], and the reliability of results analyzed by these data might be low. Nevertheless, the incorporation of iron and copper is confirmed, the existence of them is most likely Fe(III) and Cu(II) according to the positions [33], and Fe(III) positions of doped iron (Fe-SBA-15) and iron oxides (Fe/SBA-15) are different. In Fig. S3(d)-(f) and (j)-(n), the morphology of support materials (i.e., Al2O3 and SBA-15 (Fe-SBA-15)) can be observed, while no visible iron or copper oxides like those in Fig. S3 (b) and (c) can be observed. These results indicate that Al2O3 and SBA-15 have support effect for dispersion enhancement and particle size restriction of Fe2O3 and CuO [34,35], which can be also confirmed by that Fe2O3 and CuO can catalyze Fenton-like reactions for more HO• generation with Al2O3 or SBA-15 support (
Figs. 1 and 2).

The catalysts in group (v), representing complexed iron and copper, have absorbance near 1510 cm−1 and 1390 cm−1 in FTIR spectra (Fig. S4(d)), which corresponds to the symmetrical vibration and asymmetrical vibration of COO- [36,37]. In addition, Fe 2p and Cu 2p binding energy positions of MIL(Fe/Cu), MIL(Fe) and MIL(Cu) shown in Fig. S2 (e) and (j) are close to Fe(III) and Cu(II) states [8,38]. XRD spectra in Fig. S1(d) show the characteristic crystalline phase in the range of 5°–30°, and SEM images in Fig. S3(g)-(i) indicate that the morphology of these three catalysts is sub-micron crystal particles, which are consistent with those in literature [37,39]. Based on above results, it can be confirmed that the catalysts in all groups were synthesized successfully. In addition, although the dispersion, size, and actual mass loading of iron/copper might be different, the chemical states and specific surface area (Table S1) of iron and copper species are similar in bimetallic and monometallic catalysts in group (ii)-(v). These might be significant for further development of the proposed strategy in subsequent investigation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Reliability and effectiveness of trapping agent inhibition

ce:section.ce:para: As organics, the high concentration trapping agents might compete active species with the model pollutant, thereby influencing analysis of multi-effect catalysis which is based on the pollutant removal efficiency. To avoid this problem, we expected to choose an agent which can trap specific active species, and use such agent with an excessive dose to determine the contribution for active species generation of multi-effect catalysis. Therefore, it is important to evaluate the main active species for pollutant removal in different iron-copper bimetallic catalyst systems. In previous studies, TF was usually used as a scavenger of HO2 •/O2 •-, due to the high reaction constant of TF and HO2 •/O2 •- (~3 × 1010 mol−1 s−1), and low reaction constant of TF and HO• (~5 × 106 mol−1 s−1) [7,40]. The specific esterase, SOD and CAT, were usually used for HO2 •/O2 •- and H2O2 inhibition [7,41]. TBA was usually used for HO• inhibition, due to the high reaction constant (~2.0 × 109 mol−1 s−1) between them [42]. Therefore, in this study, TBA, TF, CAT and SOD were used in quenching experiments as scavengers for HO•, HO2 •/O2 •-, H2O2 and HO2 •/O2 •- suppression. As shown in Fig. S5, TBA and CAT addition could significantly suppress BPS removal efficiency to less than 10%, while the inhibition of TF and SOD on BPS removal efficiency was less than 10%, in all iron-copper bimetallic catalyst systems and monometallic catalyst systems. EPR was also used for the active species analysis. As shown in Fig. S6(a), EPR spectra show quartet lines with the peak height ratio of 1:2:2:1 accounting for DMPO-HO• adduct generation [43,44], and no other strong peak exists in all spectra. With methanol addition, EPR spectra (Fig. S6(b)) show signal of DMPO-HO2 • adduct, indicating the generation of HO2 •. Therefore, the catalysis mechanisms of these iron-copper bimetallic catalysts are similar to those in previous studies (i.e., Eqs. (1)–(5)) [8,19,45,46], and the main active species generated for pollutant removal in these iron-copper bimetallic catalyst systems can be determined as HO•. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. S7, adsorption of different catalysts hardly removed 10 mmol/L BA, with or without trapping agent addition. Consequently, to avoid the competition of HO• by trapping agents, excessive BA (10 mmol/L) was used for HO• trapping and determination in subsequent experiments [26,27].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of trapping agents on iron and copper catalysis
ce:section.ce:para: Different trapping agents for Fe(II) and Cu(I) complexation were investigated. Fig. 1 and Fig. S9 exhibit the inhibition efficiency of different trapping agents on HO• generation. With BPY and ferrozine addition, HO• generation was significantly suppressed, and the inhibition efficiency of ferrozine was slightly better than that of BPY in iron catalysis systems. These results indicate that both BPY and ferrozine can complex with Fe(II), and the reactivity of the Fe(II) complexed compounds with H2O2 could be reduced effectively. However, it should be noted that BPY and ferrozine can inhibit ~90% HO• generation, while still ~10% of HO• was generated compared with iron catalysis systems without trapping agent addition. The inhibition of neocuproine on copper catalyzed Fenton-like processes was investigated as well. Similar to the law in iron catalysis processes, neocuproine efficiently inhibited 82.4%–89.6% HO• generation by copper catalysis.

The influence of trapping agents on non-target metals (e.g., BPY and ferrozine on Cu(I), neocuproine on Fe(II)) was evaluated, as shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S9. Influence rate indicates the decrease rate of HO• generation caused by the influence of trapping agents on non-target metals. With neocuproine addition, HO• generation was influenced slightly in iron-based catalysis systems, which only decreased 9.1%, 7.7%, 9.8%, 7.9% and 5.2% in Fe2O3, Fe/Al2O3, Fe-SBA-15, Fe/SBA-15 and MIL(Fe) catalyzed Fenton-like systems, respectively. BPY and ferrozine only reduced 6.5%–9.8% and 7.3%–11.3% HO• generation, respectively, in different copper catalyst systems. As shown in Fig. S10, neocuproine addition in iron-based Fenton-like systems and ferrozine addition in copper-based Fenton-like systems were inefficient to impact H2O2 consumption. These results further confirm that trapping agents showed low influence on non-target metals catalyzed Fenton-like processes.

Above results suggest that the form of iron/copper, including iron/copper oxides (Fe2O3 and CuO), supported iron/copper oxides (Fe/Al2O3, Cu/Al2O3, Fe/SBA-15 and Cu/SBA-15), doped iron (Fe-SBA-15) and complexed iron/copper (MIL(Fe) and MIL(Cu)), did not influence the specific trapping of BPY, ferrozine and neocuproine. These trapping agents showed high inhibition efficiency and low influence rate in all these five groups of monometals catalyzed Fenton-like systems. However, the influence and missing inhibition might still influence the accuracy of the proposed strategy for analysis of iron-copper bimetallic catalysis. Therefore, we tried to calculate the inhibition efficiency and influence rate (with the data at treatment time of 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) of these three trapping agents for different catalysts. The results were summarized in Fig. 3, which we expected to use for results correction of the strategy for analysis of multi-effect catalysis in subsequent experiments.

Meanwhile, Zeta potential, Raman spectra and UV/VIS/NIR spectra of bimetallic catalysts before and after use (with trapping agent addition) were characterized as well, to evaluate possible effect of trapping agent and BA using on bimetallic catalysts. As shown in Fig. S11, Zeta potential of these catalysts slightly decreased after use with various pH, which was caused by the adsorption of BA on their surface. As shown in Fig. S12, Raman spectra of CuFe2O4 showed similar characteristic absorbance with those of CuFe2O4 by previous studies [47,48], spectra of Fe/Cu/Al2O3 showed characteristic peaks of Fe2O3 and CuO [30], and MIL(Fe/Cu) showed the peaks corresponding to carboxyl groups [49]. In addition, after used for Fenton-like catalysis with trapping agent addition, the main peaks in spectra of these catalysts remained. As shown in Fig. S13, diffuse reflectance spectra of the catalysts were similar before and after use as well. After used for Fenton-like catalysis with BA and trapping agent addition, some BA was adsorbed on the surface of catalysts, and no obvious change of their structure was found. These results further confirm that the addition of BA and trapping agents in Fenton-like systems hardly impacts catalytic activity of the catalysts.

ce:section.ce:section-title: pH range for application of trapping agent inhibition
ce:section.ce:para: pH might influence the coordination bonds between trapping agents and metals, thereby influencing the inhibition efficiency. Therefore, effect of pH on inhibition of different trapping agents was evaluated for application scope identification. The groups of Fe/Cu/Al2O3, Fe/Cu/Al2O3 and Fe/Cu/Al2O3 were used for the evaluation, and the results are shown in Fig. S14 and Fig. 4. Ferrozine showed the inhibition efficiency of 76.3%–78.3%, 88.4%–90.9%, 90.5%–82.2% and 86.8%–90.3% in Fe/Al2O3 systems; neocuproine showed the inhibition efficiency of 67.5%–71.2%, 78.0%–84.0%, 84.5%–89.6% and 81.5%–87.1% in Cu/Al2O3 systems; ferrozine and neocuproine showed the inhibition efficiency of 77.7%–79.1%, 86.7%–88.4%, 91.5%−92.8% and 90.2%–91.3% in Fe/Cu/Al2O3 with pH of 3, 4, 5 and 6, respectively. Previous studies indicate that magenta Fe(ligand)3 2+ species can form completely, with ferrozine as the ligand, between pH of 4–9[50]; neocuproine can trap Cu(I) effectively with high absorbance of formed complexing species with pH of 4–6[51]. The results in this study indicate that ferrozine and neocuproine could satisfactorily trap Fe(II) and Cu(I), respectively, with pH of 4–6, which is consistent with the literature. Consequently, the proposed strategy can be applied under weak acid for analysis of multi-effect catalysis.

Based on above results for reliability evaluation and inhibition/influence analysis, the strategy was applied in iron-copper bimetallic catalyst systems. We used ferrozine, BPY or neocuproine alone for iron or copper catalysis suppression in these five bimetallic catalysis systems. Ferrozine and neocuproine were added together as well to reinspect the reliability of trapping agent usage. As shown in Fig. 5, with both neocuproine and ferrozine addition, more than 90% HO• generation could be inhibited in all systems, which further confirms the effectiveness of these agents for metal trapping. In bimetallic systems, with ferrozine or BPY addition, Fe(II) catalytic reaction can be suppressed. Although the redox reaction between iron and copper (Eq. (5)) can occur, additional formed Fe(II) still cannot catalyze for HO• generation. Therefore, ferrozine or BPY addition systems only remain copper alone catalyzed Fenton-like reaction. With neocuproine addition, Cu(I) is complexed, and thus it hardly reacts with Fe(III) or H2O2. Copper alone catalyzed Fenton-like reaction (Eq. (3)) and iron-copper synergistic reaction (Eq. (5)) are inhibited. Therefore, neocuproine addition systems only remain iron alone catalyzed Fenton-like reaction. The synergistic enhancement can be calculated by the difference of bimetallic catalysis systems, and iron & copper alone catalysis systems (i.e., ferrozine/BPY addition systems and neocuproine addition systems). Based on HO• generation in different systems in Fig. 5, the contribution of multi-effect catalysis, i.e., iron alone catalysis, copper alone catalysis and synergistic effect, were concluded and summarized in Fig. 6.

Efficiencies of multi-effect catalysis were obtained by the proposed strategy. Nevertheless, as shown in Fig. 3, since the inhibition efficiency of trapping agents was not 100%, and the trapping agents showed slight interference on non-target metals (i.e., BPY/ferrozine on copper and neocuproine on iron), the analytical results might have considerable deviation. Compared bimetallic catalysts with corresponding monometallic catalysts, although the dispersion, morphology and actual mass loading of iron/copper might be different, the species is similar in groups (ii)-(v), which has been proved by characterizations of different catalysts in above investigation. Therefore, we tried to correct the results using inhibition efficiency and influence rate backcalculation, which were obtained by corresponding monometallic catalyst systems in each group (see Fig. 3), and the corrected results are shown in Fig. 6. First of all, it should be noted that correction of the results in CuFe2O4 system is suspect, because the species of iron/copper in Fe2O3/CuO and CuFe2O4 (group (i)) might be different. The correction strategy is not universally applicable, and could only be used with monometallic catalyst system establishment of similar metal species. Compared experimental results with the corrected one, the effect of copper alone catalysis was overrated before correction, which was caused by the fact that inhibition efficiency of neocuproine on copper (80.1%–87.8%) is lower in all systems. The effect of iron alone catalysis was similar before and after correction in all systems, with deviation less than 7%. Since synergetic effect was calculated by the difference values, it was underestimated without correction.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Comparisons of in-situ strategy and ex-situ strategy
ce:section.ce:para: The results analyzed by in-situ strategy (after correction) and ex-situ strategy (i.e., current method) were also compared, as shown in Fig. 7. By ex-situ strategy, effect of iron monometallic catalysis (i.e., Fe2O3, Fe/Al2O3, Fe-SBA-15, Fe/SBA-15 and MIL(Fe)) represents that of iron alone catalyzed Fenton-like reaction. Effect of copper monometallic catalysis (i.e., CuO, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/SBA-15 and MIL(Cu)) represents that of copper alone catalyzed Fenton-like reaction. The synergistic enhancement was calculated by the different values of bimetallic catalysis systems, and iron & copper alone catalysis systems. As mentioned above, the species of iron/copper in Fe2O3/CuO and CuFe2O4 might be significantly different. Therefore, representing iron alone and copper alone catalysis by using Fe2O3 and CuO systems is highly suspect. However, despite the limitation for correction of such catalysts, the proposed strategy (without correction) still seems acceptable for iron-copper-based catalyst analysis, which suggests wider possible application scope of in-situ strategy. In other four groups, the effect of copper alone catalysis seems overrated by ex-situ analysis. It can be explained by that reaction between iron and copper (Eq. (5)) cannot occur in copper monometallic catalysis system, and thus more Cu(I) was accumulated, which catalyzed copper-based Fenton-like reaction for more HO• generation (Eq. (3)). The effect of iron alone catalysis seems underestimated by ex-situ analysis, which might be caused by the different dispersion, morphology, actual mass loading and support effect of iron in monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. Due to the biased analysis of iron and copper alone catalysis, the synergistic enhancement obtained by the difference values, was also different from that by the in-situ strategy. Consequently, the new proposed strategy in this study shows wider scope of application, and is more accurate for multi-effect and synergistic enhancement analysis in iron-copper bimetals catalyzed Fenton-like systems.

In this study, a new in-situ strategy was proposed for the analysis of multi-effect catalysis in bimetallic catalyst systems. The reliability of trapping agents for iron/copper catalysis suppression was confirmed by the high inhibition efficiency for target metals and low influence rate for nontarget metals in monometallic catalyst systems. Five different groups of catalysts and effect of pH on inhibition were investigated to clarify the possible application scope of the developed strategy. Based on above results, the trapping method was used in bimetallic catalyst systems, and effect of multifunctional catalysis were obtained. Moreover, using inhibition efficiency and influence rate obtained in monometallic catalyst systems, the effects were corrected, which further improved the accuracy of this strategy for analysis of bimetallic catalysts. Finally, the concluded results by this in-situ strategy were compared with those by ex-situ strategy. The analysis indicates that overrated copper catalysis and biased analysis of iron catalysis by ex-situ strategy can be alleviated by the new strategy, thereby improving accuracy for synergistic effect analysis. In summary, this study provides a new strategy for mechanisms analysis of multi-effect catalysis in iron-copper bimetals catalyzed Fenton-like systems, and it is also possible to develop the strategy for other polymetallic catalysis investigations.

Yi Ren: Methodology, Validation, Formal analysis, Investigation, Data curation, Writing – original draft, Funding acquisition. Jinyan Yu: Investigation, Writing – review & editing. Jingyue Zhang: Formal analysis. Lu Lv: Methodology. Weiming Zhang: Conceptualization, Methodology, Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition.
